title: Allows a small claims proceeding where an aggrieved owner is not timely notified of the results of a properly filed grievance
summary: Permits an aggrieved real property owner to file a small claims action where he or she is not notified of the results of a grievance properly filed within the time period provided by law, and refunds the $25.00 filing fee in such cases.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S1905

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the real property tax law, in relation
to the procedure for
reviewing small claims in certain cases

PURPOSE OR GENERAL IDEA OF BILL:
The bill allows a small claims
proceeding where an aggrieved owner is not timely notified of the
results of a properly filed real property tax assessment grievance.

SUMMARY OF SPECIFIC PROVISIONS:
Where an aggrieved property owner
filed a petition for review of his/her tax assessment with the local
authorities and has not received the notice of determination at least
seven business days prior to the last day to file the small claims
petition, such owner shall be entitled to commence such small claims
proceeding. In such case, the fee would be refunded regardless of
outcome. The property owner would be advised of this petition
procedure on the form upon which a complaint is filed with the local
authorities.

EFFECTS OF PRESENT LAW WHICH THIS BILL WOULD ALTER:
Subdivision 10 is added to section 730 of the real property tax law.

JUSTIFICATION:
The current statutory deadline to file for a judicial
review of a tax assessment (30 days after the completion of the final
assessment rolls or in New York City by October 24th) has precluded
many property owners from pursuing such a remedy. Notwithstanding the
filing of a timely application to appeal the assessment with the
local tax commission or assessment, numerous property owners have
been unable to exercise their rights in the small claims forum
because they either never received a final determination or offer
from the local tax commission or assessment or they received a notice
of the determination too late to act. By authorizing a small claims
proceeding where an aggrieved owner is not timely notified of the
results by local authorities, the enactment of this bill will
preserve an existing right and will enable property owners to fulfill
the legislative intent of property tax relief for homeowners as
stated in Chapter 1022 L 1981.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
Immediately and shall apply to petitions filed against
assessment rolls prepared on or after the first of January next
succeeding the date on which it shall have become law.
